p.s: In the following text I am going to analyse Barnier's speech focusing on the way he conveys his criticism of Brexit considering servalseveral rethoricalrhetorical and stylistic factors.
He starts ofoff his argumentation with his personal opinion.
He makes clear that he thinks the Brexit is a major mistake (ll. 1f.) and that the UK will suffer from this decision (ll. 2f.).
To strengthen his argumentation he uses including pronouns like we and our (l. 2, l. 15, l. 16).
He uses these to create a relationship with his audience, but also to convince them of having the same political aims and intrestsinterests as he does.
Barnier sticks to strong negativlynegatively affected words, such as deeply regret (l. 1), while talking about Brexit, you can find these in the whole exerptexcerpt.
With this stylistic device the speaker trystries to create a bad image of the Brexit.
When talking about the EU as an open jurisdiction for financial services, he uses quite positive words and many superlatives, like most open (l. 24) or comprehensive and rule-based (l. 24).
Barnier therefore creates a positive and strong image of the EU as a market.
To strengthen the images the speaker uses many enoumerationsenumerations (e.g. ll. 6ff., ll. 11ff., ll. 28ff.).
To go on with his line of argument Barnier focuses on the bad aspects the Brexit has and will have on trading for the EU and the UK.
He states it as a lose-lose situation.
The commissioner then continues by pointing out the consequences of the Brexit for firms.
He especially meantionsmentions that these also count for subsidiaries of US firms.
He therefore appeals to all the firms affected to be prepared and ready to act.

Barnier then argues that having a close relationship with the UK would benefit both the EU and the US, especially financially and therefore is a shared goal in the EACCEuropean American Chamber of Commerce.
He then instantainiously shows up serveralseveral ways to achiveachieve this goal.

The commissioner then focuses on the EU as a market and goes on with a rethoricalrhetorical question (l. 25f.) trying to get his audience to think about, why the UK will need another system for trading with EU members than the US.

He then finishes his argumentation by stating that the EU will not change because of the Brexit and will remain open for other countries and this is well known for the US and it'sits companies, which are and shall remain shaping for the EU.
He ends his speech like this to have a remaining image of a strong EU market, but also to show how locrativelucrative the market is for the US and will stay in the future.
The language is quite argumentative as it is Barnier's aim to convince the members of the EACCEuropean American Chamber of Commerce and the public of a strong locrativelucrative EU market.
